Example 2: When your king is in danger, prioritize safety. Castling with '[e1g1]' moves your king to safety behind pawns.

Example 3: Look for tactical opportunities. If opponent's queen is undefended, move your knight with '[g1f3]' to attack it and gain material advantage.

[White] Black’s knight now covers g5, but his f7 pawn is still the only defender of the king-side dark squares.  
The c4-bishop and the d1-queen already aim at f7.  
So I’ll pile up the pressure immediately: [b1c3] develops the queen-knight to its best square, hits d5 and e4, and leaves the option of castling short next turn (it clears f1 for the king if needed).

I’ll castle kingside next, and if Black hasn’t bolstered f7 by then I can look at sacrifices (e.g. ♘xf7).
